item.title: Stop What You‚Äôre Doing In Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A And Go To This Museum
item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôm very early in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A, but I just found something in Lumiose City I had to tell somebody about, or I might explode. The RPG‚Äôs map is small, but if you‚Äôre not looking in every corner, you might miss a hole-in-the-wall establishment that could enrich the game for you. That‚Äôs what nearly happened to me, but luckily, I did stumble upon the Lumiose Museum in the northeast corner of the city.

If you‚Äôve played Pok√©mon Legends: Arceus, you‚Äôre gonna want to stop by this place and check out one of this museum‚Äôs exhibits. As I passed by, a citizen remarked that it had a showcase of artifacts from the Hisui region, which was enough to make me spin on my heel and beeline into the building. Arceus players will know that Hisui is the previous name of the Sinnoh region from Diamond and Pearl, and the historical setting of the last Legends game. Anyone who played Arceus to the end knows it ended on a bittersweet cliffhanger that seemingly doomed its isekai‚Äôd main character and others to a primitive point in history, even while they had friends, family, and Pok√©mon waiting for them in the present day. However, the Lumiose Museum‚Äôs exhibit may give us at least a few details about what happened after Arceus‚Äô conclusion.

Once you‚Äôre there, head to the second floor and you‚Äôll see several familiar artifacts from the Hisui region. There are hieroglyphics of legendary Sinnoh Pok√©mon, hand-crafted early Pok√© Balls, and a few outfits previously worn by characters like Arceus‚Äô protagonist, the surprise villain Volo, and Commander Kamado, an ancestor of Professor Rowan from Diamond and Pearl. While we don‚Äôt see anything belonging to him, one of the displays mentions a man named Ingo who would train people in Jubilife Village in the ways of Pok√©mon battles, but long-time fans will know that he was much more than that.

Ingo made his debut in Pok√©mon Black and White as an elite trainer at the Battle Subway alongside his brother Emmet. His appearance in Arceus indicated he‚Äôd been shot through time just as the protagonist had been, only to have gradually forgotten his previous life in the modern day. It was an incredibly dark and tragic fate for a Pok√©mon character, and because Arceus ended without either of these displaced trainers going back home, fans have spent the past three years assuming they lived out the rest of their lives in Hisui and never saw their loved ones again. In the case of Ingo, at least, that doesn‚Äôt seem to be the case.

The diagram of Ingo‚Äôs old training grounds has an accompanying text that says Ingo one day ‚Äúsimply vanished‚Äù after telling the people of Jubilife that it was ‚Äútime for [him] to return.‚Äù Though we haven‚Äôt seen Ingo in any games since, it sounds like he did get to go home to his brother and friends eventually. 

The long-lost time traveler isn‚Äôt the only character we get an update on in the exhibit. Volo, the ancestor of Diamond and Pearl champion Cynthia and a surprise religious zealot intent on usurping Arceus‚Äô power for himself, also gets an epilogue of sorts in Legends: Z-A. You can find his final boss outfit in a glass case next to statues of legendary Pok√©mon Palkia and Dialga, and one of the museum‚Äôs patrons says that the person who wore it donated it to the exhibit personally. He also apparently looked at some of the sketches on display ‚Äúwith this nostalgic air,‚Äù implying that Volo has, somehow, persisted into the modern day. Is he time-traveling? Is he immortal? Will we see his crazy ass again? I have so many new questions.

Whatever happened to Volo and Ingo, it also stands to reason that Arceus‚Äô protagonist was likely able to return to the modern day as well, though I haven‚Äôt been able to find any direct mention of their whereabouts. Their uniform is on display here, though. So one way or another, history has not forgotten them and what they accomplished in Hisui all those years ago.

item.title: Pok√©mon Legends Z-A‚Äôs Small, Boring Map Is Leaving Fans Disappointed
item.content:encoded:
Pok√©mon Legends Z-A, the newest entry in the long-running Nintendo RPG franchise, is officially out today on Switch and Switch 2. And while many are excited to hop in and start catching pocket monsters, many fans aren‚Äôt happy with Z-A‚Äòs small and boring map, which lacks the environmental variety found in past Pok√©mon games.

While Pok√©mon Legends Z-A technically didn‚Äôt launch until today, October 16, fans have been playing leaked versions of the game for a few weeks now and have begun sharing their thoughts online about the game‚Äôs map, which is the entirety of Lumiose City, located in the Kalos region. This location first appeared in 2013‚Äôs Pok√©mon X and Y. In those games, Lumiose City was just one of many locations included in the large open world. However, in Z-A, Lumiose City is essentially the entire playspace, and that‚Äôs proving to be a disappointing fact for some players.

Over on the Pok√©mon subreddit, a popular post with over 3,000 upvotes claims that you can walk around the entire city in less than seven minutes. Eurogamer tested this out and confirmed that, yes, if you sprint around and avoid battles, you can run around the whole circular city in just about six minutes and 20 seconds. Now, a smaller map isn‚Äôt entirely a bad thing. Some open worlds don‚Äôt need much space to be wonderful. Grand Theft Auto 3 feels pretty dang small when you go back to it in 2025, but it packs a lot in its limited sandbox. However, Z-A‚Äôs map isn‚Äôt just small, it also lacks visual variety. This is demonstrated perfectly in this short video from YouTuber 101Leafy. 

On Reddit and YouTube, you can find comments from players lamenting the small map‚Äôs lack of visual variety. For a franchise that used to be about discovering new cities, towns, biomes, and environments, Z-A‚Äòs focus on one city, filled with reused buildings and props, is disappointing to many. And while some of the complaints are clearly from fans who have long been done with the series but can‚Äôt stop torturing themselves, the more you look at screenshots and videos of Z-A, the more it becomes clear that, yeah, there ain‚Äôt much here.

At least if you buy the game on Switch, it mostly looks the same as the Switch 2 version. Don‚Äôt worry, everyone gets to enjoy the same copy-pasted buildings regardless of their platform of choice. That‚Äôs nice.

item.title: Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A Has Changed Shiny Hunting Forever, And Not Everyone‚Äôs Happy About It
item.content:encoded:
Shiny hunting is a beloved pastime for many Pok√©mon fans. Finding these rare critters with different shades and color palettes than their species‚Äô default appearance is such an involved undertaking with secret math and other nonsense to contend with that some people spend hours looking for just one of these guys. Others spend even longer trying to find one of every ‚Äòmon in the Pok√©dex. Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A is out today, and players have discovered the RPG has made one crucial change to Shiny hunting that has taken some of the difficulty out of this process, and while some fans are rejoicing, others are lamenting how much easier it‚Äôs gotten to capture these alternate-colored Pok√©mon.

When you enter Legends: Z-A‚Äôs Wild Zones, designated areas where wild Pok√©mon live and can be captured, typically every monster you encounter is refreshed when the game‚Äôs day and night cycle changes, your party is knocked out, or if you fast travel. However, that doesn‚Äôt seem to be the case for Shinies. Players have tested this on Pok√©mon they‚Äôve found in the overworld, and it seems like, unless you defeat it in battle, Shiny Pok√©mon don‚Äôt despawn. 

I found a Shiny Magikarp. I changed to nighttime to make it disappear and back to daytime and it was still there.

I fast traveled away and back and it was still there.

I had my character knocked out and came back and it was still there.

Enjoy pic.twitter.com/tA42rUM9iv

‚Äî SBCoop (@SBCoop89) October 15, 2025

LZA has special behavior to keep shiny Pok√©mon from despawning! This looks to be intentional. The game stashes up to 10 shiny Pok√©mon and keeps them from despawning if you leave the area.

Essentially, nonshinies are rerolled but shinies are not, as you can see here in this clip. pic.twitter.com/FHo3uqAR7R

‚Äî Anubis (@Sibuna_Switch) October 16, 2025

can confirm this too! ü§Ø

I thought i accidentally depsawned a shiny cuz the sound played after i was already walking up the stairs to a new area ‚Äì went back down and it was still there!!

love that they added a shiny failsafe! this is HUGE#PokemonLegendsZA https://t.co/0OroFXjVuc pic.twitter.com/F6DG8XvvDk

‚Äî Junzz (@junzztv) October 16, 2025

This means that there‚Äôs now significantly less risk during Shiny hunting, as Legends: Z-A goes out of its way to make sure you have a chance to engage with these monsters before they disappear forever. It is still possible to lose out on a Shiny, though. If you knock it out or if you scare a skittish Pok√©mon off, that‚Äôs that. So some risk does remain. 

As Shiny hunting has become easier thanks to items like the Shiny Charm, which increases their (still minuscule) spawn rates, longtime fans have stopped seeing collecting these rare Pok√©mon as a badge of honor, while others are just glad that they‚Äôve become less frustrating to catch. Missing out on a Shiny can feel devastating, and fucking it up may lead to viral moments, but would you rather have a funny story or a Shiny Pok√©mon in your collection?

This isn't just a quality-of-life update. It's the death of a legend.

The thrill of finding a shiny was always magnified by the heartbreaking risk of losing it.

By removing the risk, they have guaranteed the reward. But they have also removed the story you would tell for the‚Ä¶

am i the only one that feels like this depreciates the value of a shiny? like what even is the point of them now

While this is new to Legends: Z-A, the game also brought back an old Shiny-hunting quality-of-life feature from Legends: Arceus that Scarlet and Violet did away with. Now, if a Shiny Pok√©mon spawns nearby, you‚Äôll hear a short jingle to signal to you that it‚Äôs somewhere in your vicinity. It always felt weird that Scarlet and Violet skipped out on a feature that was especially helpful for colorblind players who might not be able to clock a Shiny at first glance, so it‚Äôs nice to see Z-A bring it back.
